awd_titl_txt: Integrating Culturally Relevant Pedagogy in Math Instruction at a Hispanic-Serving Community College to Increase Student Engagement and Success
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving instructional practices in math education at an Hispanic-serving institution through the integration of culturally relevant pedagogical practices. A cohort of math faculty at the Norco Campus of Riverside Community College will pilot this professional development approach aimed at improving instructional practice in mathematics courses ranging from Math for Liberal Arts to Calculus. The project will also assign an educational advisor to work in tandem with participating math faculty to address student support issues. The intent of the project is to improve success, retention, and persistence for students in STEM fields through a combination of improved instructional techniques and student support services. The project will advance the scientific community’s understanding of how culturally relevant and sustaining pedagogy influences classroom practices and student outcomes.

Two goals guide the project. First is to support an initial group of three math faculty to develop culturally relevant and sustainable pedagogies while simultaneously enhancing support structures for students with a dedicated educational advisor. Second is to increase the number of students who successfully complete transfer-level math courses in their first year as students at a Hispanic-serving community college.  The faculty in the cohort will make changes in six different courses, which will impact at least 900 students over the lifetime of the award.  Through presentations and increased collaboration with the rest of the math department at Norco College, this pilot project has the potential to become a larger more transformative initiative that could expand throughout the Riverside Community College District.  Results from the impacted courses will be compared to traditional courses, which will provide new knowledge on the impact of employing culturally responsive pedagogies and dedicated advising on the success, retention, and completion rates for students at Hispanic-serving community colleges.  The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education, broaden participation in STEM, and build capacity at HSIs. Achieving these aims, given the diverse nature and context of the HSIs, requires innovative approaches that incentivize institutional and community transformation and promote fundamental research (i) on engaged student learning, (ii) about what it takes to diversify and increase participation in STEM effectively, and (iii) that improves our understanding of how to build institutional capacity at HSIs.  Projects supported by the HSI Program will also draw from these approaches to generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Faculty Learning Community (FLC) project demonstrated a commitment to enhancing teaching practices and student success through the integration of evidence-based teaching practices (EBTPs) and ongoing faculty collaboration. The participants' efforts highlighted several areas of growth. 1. Implementation of EBTPs: Faculty members successfully implemented various evidence-based teaching strategies, including flexible deadlines, more inclusive syllabi, and personalized support for underrepresented student groups. 2. Impact of Faculty on Student Success: Faculty consistently noted positive outcomes from their efforts, such as improved student engagement, stronger relationships with students, and increased retention. 3. Integration of Academic Advisors: The inclusion of academic advisors aimed to further support students by providing a resource outside the classroom.

The FLC was successful in achieving the grant’s primary goals, particularly in motivating faculty to experiment with new teaching practices and fostering an inclusive classroom environment. One of the most notable outcomes was the shift away from lecture-based teaching to a more interactive learning style.  Another major focus of the FLC was creating an inclusive classroom culture. The collaborative structure of the FLC allowed faculty to exchange ideas for building such environments.  A third focus area was grading reform. The participants discussed how rigid grading systems disproportionately penalize non-traditional students, who often face competing priorities such as jobs and family responsibilities.

Throughout the project, student feedback was collected at the beginning and end of each semester (Fall 2022, Spring 2023, and Fall 2023) to assess their experiences with their courses and interactions with academic advisors.

At the start of both Spring and Fall 2023 semesters, most students reported that their instructors cared about their success and had a growth mindset. Students also felt comfortable approaching their instructors with questions or comments. However, there was less agreement on course difficulty and the use of campus resources. 

In Fall 2023, additional questions were added to the pre-test to assess students' experiences with their academic advisor (as this element was added as part of the project). While most students agreed that their advisor listened to their concerns (92%) and provided support (84%), fewer felt their advisor knew them well (40%) or were comfortable sharing personal challenges(43%). Many students found it easy to schedule appointments with their advisor (78%) and felt their emails were answered in a timely manner (89%). Nearly all students (96%) felt comfortable during their meetings, and 69% said their advisor referred them to campus resources. 

By the end of each semester, students consistently reported feeling welcome in their classes and appreciated their instructors' attention to their progress. However, student responses were more variable when asked about class preparation and awareness of on-campus resources. 

In the Fall 2023 post-test, students continued to report mixed experiences with their academic advisors. Over a quarter of students (27%) had never met with their advisor, while 26% met with them frequently. Most students felt heard (80%) and supported (79%) during their interactions, though many (72-76%) said their advisor did not ask about life responsibilities. A slightly higher percentage (40%) said their advisor asked about the campus resources they were using. 

Many students still found it relatively easy to schedule meetings with their advisor (81%), and almost all felt comfortable in those meetings (98%). However, fewer students (53%) were referred to campus resources, with some noting they did not need a referral. Nearly half (49%) said they would recommend their advisor to other students. 

Due to the anonymity of the data, it was not possible to run within-subject test designs to assess changes over time. As a result, the focus shifted to analyzing descriptive information and identifying differences in students' post-test experiences across the three semesters. No significant differences in students’ responses to any of the nine post-test items across the Fall 2022, Spring 2023, and Fall 2023 semesters were found.

Course success rates (i.e., grades A-C or pass), provided by the Office of Institutional Effectiveness, were compared across the three semesters to determine whether there were any significant differences in student outcomes. Overall, student success rates dropped slightly between the baseline semester (Fall 2022) and the treatment semesters (Spring 2023 and Fall 2023); however, the difference was non-significant. Given that the implementation of new EBTPs is often associated with a temporary decline in student outcomes as faculty experiment and refine new teaching strategies, these findings indicate that the impact of the changes did not negatively affect overall student performance.

Success rates in courses taught by FLC participants were compared to sections of the same course taught by non-participating faculty. The analysis showed that FLC-member instructed courses either had significantly higher or equal success rates compared to their counterpart sections taught by non-FLC faculty. This suggests that the integration of EBTPs by FLC members had a neutral or positive impact on student success, further validating the effectiveness of the teaching strategies implemented by participating faculty.


Last Modified: 01/22/2025
Modified by: Caroline Hutchings

Impact of Faculty on Student Success: Faculty consistently noted positive outcomes from their efforts, such as improved student engagement, stronger relationships with students, and increased retention. 3. Integration of Academic Advisors: The inclusion of academic advisors aimed to further support students by providing a resource outside the classroom.
